00017 /** The namespace for all Max object classes which can be instantiated in a box, i.e. in a patcher.
00018     @ingroup class */
00019 #define CLASS_BOX               gensym("box")
00020 
00021 /** A namespace for creating hidden or internal object classes which are not a direct part of the user 
00022     creating patcher.
00023     @ingroup class */
00024 #define CLASS_NOBOX             gensym("nobox")
00025 
00026 
00027 /** Attribute flags
00028     @ingroup attr
00029 */
00030 typedef enum {
00031     ATTR_FLAGS_NONE =       0x0000000,  ///< No flags
00032     ATTR_GET_OPAQUE =       0x00000001, ///< The attribute cannot be queried by either max message when used inside of a CLASS_BOX object, nor from C code.
00033     ATTR_SET_OPAQUE =       0x00000002, ///< The attribute cannot be set by either max message when used inside of a CLASS_BOX object, nor from C code.
00034     ATTR_GET_OPAQUE_USER =  0x00000100, ///< The attribute cannot be queried by max message when used inside of a CLASS_BOX object, but <em>can</em> be queried from C code.
00035     ATTR_SET_OPAQUE_USER =  0x00000200, ///< The attribute cannot be set by max message when used inside of a CLASS_BOX object, but <em>can</em> be set from C code.
00036     ATTR_GET_DEFER =        0x00010000, ///< Any attribute queries will be called through a defer().
00037     ATTR_GET_USURP =        0x00020000, ///< Any calls to query the attribute will be called through the equivalent of a defer(), repeated calls will be ignored until the getter is actually run.
00038     ATTR_GET_DEFER_LOW =    0x00040000, ///< Any attribute queries will be called through a defer_low().
00039     ATTR_GET_USURP_LOW =    0x00080000, ///< Any calls to query the attribute will be called through the equivalent of a defer_low(), repeated calls will be ignored until the getter is actually run.
00040     ATTR_SET_DEFER =        0x01000000, ///< The attribute setter will be called through a defer().
00041     ATTR_SET_USURP =        0x02000000, ///< Any calls to set the attribute will be called through the equivalent of a defer_low(), repeated calls will be ignored until the setter is actually run.
00042     ATTR_SET_DEFER_LOW =    0x04000000, ///< The attribute setter will be called through a defer_low().
00043     ATTR_SET_USURP_LOW =    0x08000000  ///< Any calls to set the attribute will be called through the equivalent of a defer_low(), repeated calls will be ignored until the setter is actually run.
00044 } e_max_attrflags;
00045

00047 /** Standard values returned by function calls with a return type of #t_max_err
00048     @ingroup misc */
00049 typedef enum {
00050     MAX_ERR_NONE =          0,  ///< No error
00051     MAX_ERR_GENERIC =       -1, ///< Generic error
00052     MAX_ERR_INVALID_PTR =   -2, ///< Invalid Pointer
00053     MAX_ERR_DUPLICATE =     -3, ///< Duplicate
00054     MAX_ERR_OUT_OF_MEM =    -4  ///< Out of memory
00055 } e_max_errorcodes;

00058 /** Flags used in linklist and hashtab objects 
00059     @ingroup datastore */
00060 typedef enum {
00061     OBJ_FLAG_OBJ =      0x00000000, ///< free using object_free()
00062     OBJ_FLAG_REF =      0x00000001, ///< don't free
00063     OBJ_FLAG_DATA =     0x00000002, ///< don't free data or call method
00064     OBJ_FLAG_MEMORY =   0x00000004, ///< don't call method, and when freeing use sysmem_freeptr() instead of freeobject 
00065     OBJ_FLAG_SILENT =   0x00000100  ///< don't notify when modified
00066 } e_max_datastore_flags;

00069 #ifdef calcoffset //find better place for this?
00070     // The ifdefs for this macro have been set up like this so that Doxygen can document this macro on a Mac [TAP]
00071 #else
00072     #ifdef WIN_VERSION
00073         // rbs truncation of pointer to long is safe if the struct is smaller than 2^32 bytes.
00074         // this seems like a good assumption.  
00075         // PtrToLong is defined in Basetsd.h (windows) and is described here http://msdn2.microsoft.com/En-US/library/aa384242.aspx
00076         #define calcoffset(x,y) (PtrToLong(&(((x *)0L)->y)))
00077     #else
00078         /** 
00079             Find byte offset of a named member of a struct, relative to the beginning of that struct.
00080             @ingroup misc
00081             @param  x   The name of the struct
00082             @param  y   The name of the member
00083             @return     A long integer representing the number of bytes into the struct where the member begins.
00084         */
00085         #define calcoffset(x,y) ((long)(&(((x *)0L)->y)))
00086     #endif
00087 #endif

00096 typedef unsigned int    uint;

00099     @ingroup datatypes */

00102 /** An unsigned char.
00103     @ingroup datatypes */
00104 typedef unsigned char   uchar;

00133 /** Common attr struct. This struct is provided for debugging convenience, 
00134     but should be considered opaque and is subject to change without notice. 
00135 
00136     @ingroup attr
00137 */
00138 typedef struct _attr
00139 {
00140     t_object        ob;
00141     t_symbol        *name;
00142     t_symbol        *type;  
00143     long            flags;          //public/private get/set methods
00144     method          get;            //override default get method
00145     method          set;            //override default set method
00146     void            *filterget;     //filterobject for get method
00147     void            *filterset;     //filterobject for set method
00148     void            *reserved;      //for future use
00149 } t_attr;

00166 /**
00167     Initializes a class by informing Max of its name, instance creation and free functions, size and argument types. 
00168     Developers wishing to use obex class features (attributes, etc.) <em>must</em> use class_new() 
00169     instead of the traditional setup() function.
00170 
00171     @ingroup class
00172 
00173     @param  name    The class's name, as a C-string
00174     @param  mnew    The instance creation function
00175     @param  mfree   The instance free function
00176     @param  size    The size of the object's data structure in bytes. 
00177                     Usually you use the C sizeof operator here.
00178     @param  mmenu   The function called when the user creates a new object of the  
00179                     class from the Patch window's palette (UI objects only).  
00180                     Pass 0L if you're not defining a UI object.
00181     @param  type    A standard Max <em>type list</em> as explained in Chapter 3  
00182                     of the Writing Externals in Max document (in the Max SDK).  
00183                     The final argument of the type list should be a 0.  
00184                     <em>Generally, obex objects have a single type argument</em>,  
00185                     #A_GIMME, followed by a 0.
00186 
00187     @return         This function returns the class pointer for the new object class. 
00188                     <em>This pointer is used by numerous other functions and should be 
00189                     stored in a global or static variable.</em>
00190 */
00191 t_class *class_new(char *name, method mnew, method mfree, long size, method mmenu, short type, ...);
00192 
00193 
00194 /**
00195     Frees a previously defined object class. <em>This function is not typically used by external developers.</em>
00196 
00197     @ingroup class
00198     @param  c       The class pointer
00199     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
00200                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
00201 */
00202 t_max_err class_free(t_class *c);
00203 
00204 
00205 /**
00206     Registers a previously defined object class. This function is required, and should be called at the end of <tt>main()</tt>.
00207 
00208     @ingroup class
00209 
00210     @param  name_space  The desired class's name space. Typically, either the 
00211                         constant #CLASS_BOX, for obex classes which can 
00212                         instantiate inside of a Max patcher (e.g. boxes, UI objects, 
00213                         etc.), or the constant #CLASS_NOBOX, for classes 
00214                         which will only be used internally. Developers can define 
00215                         their own name spaces as well, but this functionality is 
00216                         currently undocumented.
00217     @param  c           The class pointer
00218 
00219     @return             This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
00220                         or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
00221 */
00222 t_max_err class_register(t_symbol *name_space, t_class *c);
00223

00225 /**
00226     Registers an alias for a previously defined object class.
00227 
00228     @ingroup class
00229     @param  c           The class pointer
00230     @param  aliasname   A symbol who's name will become an alias for the given class
00231 
00232     @return             This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
00233                         or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
00234 */
00235 t_max_err class_alias(t_class *c, t_symbol *aliasname);

00238 /**
00239     Adds a method to a previously defined object class. 
00240     
00241     @ingroup class
00242     
00243     @param  c       The class pointer
00244     @param  m       Function to be called when the method is invoked
00245     @param  name    C-string defining the message (message selector)
00246     @param  ...     One or more integers specifying the arguments to the message, 
00247                     in the standard Max type list format (see Chapter 3 of the 
00248                     Writing Externals in Max document for more information).
00249     
00250     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
00251                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
00252     
00253     @remark         The class_addmethod() function works essentially like the 
00254                     traditional addmess() function, adding the function pointed to  
00255                     by <tt>m</tt>, to respond to the message string <tt>name</tt> in the   
00256                     leftmost inlet of the object. 
00257 */
00258 t_max_err class_addmethod(t_class *c, method m, char *name, ...);
00259

00261 /**
00262     Adds an attribute to a previously defined object class. 
00263 
00264     @ingroup class
00265 
00266     @param  c       The class pointer
00267     @param  attr    The attribute to add. The attribute will be a pointer returned 
00268                     by attribute_new(), attr_offset_new() or 
00269                     attr_offset_array_new().
00270 
00271     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
00272                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
00273 */
00274 t_max_err class_addattr(t_class *c,t_object *attr);

00295 /**
00296     Finds the class pointer for a class, given the class's namespace and name.
00297 
00298     @ingroup class
00299 
00300     @param  name_space  The desired class's name space. Typically, either the 
00301                         constant #CLASS_BOX, for obex classes which can 
00302                         instantiate inside of a Max patcher (e.g. boxes, UI objects, 
00303                         etc.), or the constant #CLASS_NOBOX, for classes 
00304                         which will only be used internally. Developers can define 
00305                         their own name spaces as well, but this functionality is 
00306                         currently undocumented.
00307     @param  classname   The name of the class to be looked up
00308 
00309     @return             If successful, this function returns the class's data pointer. Otherwise, it returns NULL.
00310 */
00311 t_class *class_findbyname(t_symbol *name_space, t_symbol *classname);

00321                         instantiate inside of a Max patcher (e.g. boxes, UI objects,

00325                         currently undocumented.

00347 /**
00348     Determines if a particular object is an instance of a given class.
00349 
00350     @ingroup obj
00351 
00352     @param  x       The object to test
00353     @param  name    The name of the class to test this object against
00354     @return         This function returns 1 if the object is an instance of the named class. Otherwise, 0 is returned.
00355     @remark         For instance, to determine whether an unknown object pointer is a pointer to a print object, one would call:
00356 
00357     @code
00358     long isprint = object_classname_compare(x, gensym("print"));
00359     @endcode
00360 */
00361 long object_classname_compare(void *x, t_symbol *name);

00380 /**
00381     Allocates the memory for an instance of an object class and initialize its object header. 
00382     It is used like the traditional function newobject, inside of an object's <tt>new</tt> method, but its use is required with obex-class objects.
00383 
00384     @ingroup obj
00385     @param  c       The class pointer, returned by class_new()
00386     @return         This function returns a new instance of an object class if successful, or NULL if unsuccessful.
00387 */
00388 void *object_alloc(t_class *c);
00389

00391 /**
00392     Allocates the memory for an instance of an object class and initialize its object header <em>internal to Max</em>. 
00393     It is used similarly to the traditional function newinstance(), but its use is required with obex-class objects.
00394 
00395     @ingroup obj
00396 
00397     @param  name_space  The desired object's name space. Typically, either the 
00398                         constant #CLASS_BOX, for obex classes which can 
00399                         instantiate inside of a Max patcher (e.g. boxes, UI objects, 
00400                         etc.), or the constant #CLASS_NOBOX, for classes 
00401                         which will only be used internally. Developers can define 
00402                         their own name spaces as well, but this functionality is 
00403                         currently undocumented.
00404     @param  classname   The name of the class of the object to be created
00405     @param  ...         Any arguments expected by the object class being instantiated
00406 
00407     @return             This function returns a new instance of the object class if successful, or NULL if unsuccessful.
00408 */
00409 void *object_new(t_symbol *name_space, t_symbol *classname, ...);
00410 
00411 
00412 /**
00413     Allocates the memory for an instance of an object class and initialize its object header <em>internal to Max</em>. 
00414     It is used similarly to the traditional function newinstance(), but its use is required with obex-class objects. 
00415     The object_new_typed() function differs from object_new() by its use of an atom list for object argumentsin this way, 
00416     it more resembles the effect of typing something into an object box from the Max interface.
00417 
00418     @ingroup obj
00419 
00420     @param  name_space  The desired object's name space. Typically, either the 
00421                         constant #CLASS_BOX, for obex classes which can 
00422                         instantiate inside of a Max patcher (e.g. boxes, UI objects, 
00423                         etc.), or the constant #CLASS_NOBOX, for classes 
00424                         which will only be used internally. Developers can define 
00425                         their own name spaces as well, but this functionality is 
00426                         currently undocumented.
00427     @param  classname   The name of the class of the object to be created
00428     @param  ac          Count of arguments in <tt>av</tt>
00429     @param  av          Array of t_atoms; arguments to the class's instance creation function.
00430 
00431     @return             This function returns a new instance of the object class if successful, or NULL if unsuccessful.
00432 */
00433 void *object_new_typed(t_symbol *name_space, t_symbol *classname, long ac, t_atom *av);
00434 
00435 void *object_new_menufun(t_symbol *name_space, t_symbol *classname, void *p, long h, long v, long f);
00436 
00437 
00438 /**
00439     Call the free function and release the memory for an instance of an internal object class previously instantiated using object_new(), 
00440     object_new_typed() or other new-style object constructor functions (e.g. hashtab_new()). 
00441     It is, at the time of this writing, a wrapper for the traditional function freeobject(), but its use is suggested with obex-class objects.
00442 
00443     @ingroup obj
00444     @param  x       The pointer to the object to be freed. 
00445     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
00446                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
00447 */
00448 t_max_err object_free(void *x);

00451 /**
00452     Sends an untyped message to an object. 
00453 
00454     @ingroup obj
00455 
00456     @param  x       The object that will receive the message 
00457     @param  s       The message selector
00458     @param  ...     Any arguments to the message
00459 
00460     @return         If the receiver object can respond to the message, object_method() returns the result. Otherwise, the function will return 0. 
00461 
00462     @remark         Example: To send the message <tt>bang</tt> to the object <tt>bang_me</tt>:
00463     @code
00464     void *bang_result;
00465     bang_result = object_method(bang_me, gensym("bang"));
00466     @endcode
00467 */
00468 void *object_method(void *x, t_symbol *s, ...);
00469

00471 /**
00472     Sends a type-checked message to an object. 
00473 
00474     @ingroup obj
00475 
00476     @param  x       The object that will receive the message 
00477     @param  s       The message selector
00478     @param  ac      Count of message arguments in <tt>av</tt>
00479     @param  av      Array of t_atoms; the message arguments
00480     @param  rv      Return value of function, if available
00481 
00482     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
00483                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
00484 
00485     @remark         If the receiver object can respond to the message, object_method_typed() returns the result in <tt>rv</tt>. Otherwise, <tt>rv</tt> will contain an #A_NOTHING atom.
00486 */
00487 t_max_err object_method_typed(void *x, t_symbol *s, long ac, t_atom *av, t_atom *rv);

00498     @param  ac      Count of message arguments in <tt>av</tt>
00499     @param  av      Array of t_atoms; the message arguments
00500     @param  rv      Return value of function, if available
00501 
00502     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
00503                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
00504 
00505     @remark         If the receiver object can respond to the message, object_method_typedfun() returns the result in <tt>rv</tt>. Otherwise, <tt>rv</tt> will contain an #A_NOTHING atom.
00506 */
00507 t_max_err object_method_typedfun(void *x, t_messlist *mp, t_symbol *s, long ac, t_atom *av, t_atom *rv);

00537 /**
00538     Registers an object in a namespace.
00539 
00540     @ingroup obj
00541 
00542     @param  name_space  The namespace in which to register the object. The namespace can be any symbol.
00543                         If the namespace does not already exist, it is created automatically.
00544     @param  s           The name of the object in the namespace. This name will be 
00545                         used by other objects to attach and detach from the registered object.
00546     @param  x           The object to register
00547 
00548     @return     The function returns a pointer to the registered object. Under some 
00549                 circumstances, object_register will <em>duplicate</em> the object, 
00550                 and return a pointer to the duplicatethe developer should not assume 
00551                 that the pointer passed in is the same pointer that has been registered. 
00552                 To be safe, the returned pointer should be stored and used with the 
00553                 bject_unregister() function.
00554 */
00555 void *object_register(t_symbol *name_space, t_symbol *s, void *x);
00556

00561 /**
00562     Determines a registered object's pointer, given its namespace and name.

00564     @ingroup obj
00565     
00566     @param  name_space  The namespace of the registered object
00567     @param  s           The name of the registered object in the namespace
00568 
00569     @return     This function returns the pointer of the registered object, 
00570                 if successful, or NULL, if unsuccessful.

00572 void *object_findregistered(t_symbol *name_space, t_symbol *s);

00574 
00575 /**
00576     Determines the namespace and/or name of a registered object, given the object's pointer.
00577 
00578     @ingroup obj
00579 
00580     @param  name_space  Pointer to a t_symbol *, to receive the namespace of the registered object
00581     @param  s           Pointer to a t_symbol *, to receive the name of the registered object within the namespace
00582     @param  x           Pointer to the registered object
00583 
00584     @return     This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
00585                 or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
00586 */
00587 t_max_err object_findregisteredbyptr(t_symbol **name_space, t_symbol **s, void *x);
00588 
00589 
00590 /**
00591     Attaches a client to a registered object. 
00592     Once attached, the object will receive notifications sent from the registered object (via the object_notify() function), 
00593     if it has a <tt>notify</tt> method defined and implemented.
00594 
00595     @ingroup obj
00596 
00597     @param  name_space  The namespace of the registered object. 
00598                         This should be the same value used in object_register() to register the object.
00599                         If you don't know the registered object's namespace, the object_findregisteredbyptr() function can be used to determine it.
00600     @param  s           The name of the registered object in the namespace. 
00601                         If you don't know the name of the registered object, the object_findregisteredbyptr() function can be used to determine it.
00602     @param  x           The client object to attach. Generally, this is the pointer to your Max object. 
00603 
00604     @return     This function returns a pointer to the registered object (to the object 
00605                 referred to by the combination of <tt>name_space</tt> and <tt>s</tt> 
00606                 arguments) if successful, or NULL if unsuccessful.
00607     
00608     @see        object_notify()
00609 */
00610 void *object_attach(t_symbol *name_space, t_symbol *s, void *x);
00611 
00612 
00613 /**
00614     Detach a client from a registered object.
00615 
00616     @ingroup obj
00617 
00618     @param  name_space  The namespace of the registered object. 
00619                         This should be the same value used in object_register() to register the object.
00620                         If you don't know the registered object's namespace, the object_findregisteredbyptr() function can be used to determine it.
00621     @param  s           The name of the registered object in the namespace. 
00622                         If you don't know the name of the registered object, the object_findregisteredbyptr() function can be used to determine it.
00623     @param  x           The client object to attach. Generally, this is the pointer to your Max object. 
00624 
00625     @return     This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
00626                 or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
00627 */
00628 t_max_err object_detach(t_symbol *name_space, t_symbol *s, void *x);
00629

00631 t_max_err object_attach_byptr(void *x, void *registeredobject);

00634 t_max_err object_attach_byptr_register(void *x, void *registeredobject, t_symbol *reg_name_space);

00640 /**
00641     Removes a registered object from a namespace.
00642 
00643     @ingroup obj
00644     @param  x       The object to unregister. This should be the pointer returned from the object_register() function.
00645     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
00646                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
00647 */
00648 t_max_err object_unregister(void *x);
00649 
00650 
00651 /**
00652     Broadcast a message (with an optional argument) from a registered object to any attached client objects.
00653 
00654     @ingroup obj
00655 
00656     @param  x       Pointer to the registered object
00657     @param  s       The message to send
00658     @param  data    An optional argument which will be passed with the message. 
00659                     Sets this argument to NULL if it will be unused. 
00660 
00661     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
00662                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
00663 
00664     @remark         In order for client objects to receive notifications, they must define and implement a special method, <tt>notify</tt>, like so:
00665     @code
00666     class_addmethod(c, (method)myobject_notify, "notify", A_CANT, 0);
00667     @endcode
00668 
00669     @remark         The <tt>notify</tt> method should be prototyped as:
00670     @code
00671     void myobject_notify(t_myobject *x, t_symbol *s, t_symbol *msg, void *sender, void *data);
00672     @endcode
00673                     where 
00674                     <tt>x</tt> is the pointer to the receiving object,
00675                     <tt>s</tt> is the name of the sending (registered) object in its namespace,
00676                     <tt>msg</tt> is the sent message,
00677                     <tt>sender</tt> is the pointer to the sending object, and
00678                     <tt>data</tt> is an optional argument sent with the message. 
00679                     This value corresponds to the data argument in the object_notify() method. 
00680 */
00681 t_max_err object_notify(void *x, t_symbol *s, void *data);
00682 
00683 
00684 /**
00685     Determines the class of a given object.
00686 
00687     @ingroup obj
00688     @param  x       The object to test
00689     @return         This function returns the t_class * of the object's class, if successful, or NULL, if unsuccessful.
00690 */
00691 t_class *object_class(void *x);
00692 
00693 
00694 /**
00695     Retrieves the value of an object which supports the <tt>getvalueof/setvalueof</tt> interface. See part 2 of the pattr SDK for more information on this interface.
00696 
00697     @ingroup obj
00698 
00699     @param  x       The object whose value is of interest
00700     @param  ac      Pointer to a long variable to receive the count of arguments in <tt>av</tt>. The long variable itself should be set to 0 previous to calling this function.
00701     @param  av      Pointer to a t_atom *, to receive object data. The t_atom * itself should be set to NULL previous to calling this function.
00702 
00703     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
00704                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
00705 
00706     @remark         Calling the object_getvalueof() function allocates memory for any data it returns. 
00707                     It is the developer's responsibility to free it, using the freebytes() function.
00708                     
00709     @remark         Developers wishing to design objects which will support this function being called on them must define and implement a special method, <tt>getvalueof</tt>, like so:
00710     @code
00711     class_addmethod(c, (method)myobject_getvalueof, "getvalueof", A_CANT, 0);
00712     @endcode
00713 
00714     @remark         The <tt>getvalueof</tt> method should be prototyped as:
00715     @code
00716     t_max_err myobject_getvalueof(t_myobject *x, long *ac, t_atom **av);
00717     @endcode
00718 
00719     @remark         And implemented, generally, as:
00720     @code
00721     t_max_err myobj_getvalueof(t_myobj *x, long *ac, t_atom **av) 
00722     {
00723         if (ac && av) {
00724             if (*ac && *av) {
00725                 // memory has been passed in; use it.
00726             } else {
00727                 // allocate enough memory for your data
00728                 *av = (t_atom *)getbytes(sizeof(t_atom));
00729             }
00730             *ac = 1; // our data is a single floating point value
00731             atom_setfloat(*av, x->objvalue);
00732         }
00733         return MAX_ERR_NONE;
00734     }
00735 
00736     @remark         By convention, and to permit the interoperability of objects using the obex API, 
00737                     developers should allocate memory in their <tt>getvalueof</tt> methods using the getbytes() function. 
00738     @endcode
00739 */
00740 t_max_err object_getvalueof(void *x, long *ac, t_atom **av);
00741 
00742 
00743 /**
00744     Sets the value of an object which supports the <tt>getvalueof/setvalueof</tt> interface.
00745 
00746     @ingroup obj
00747 
00748     @param  x       The object whose value is of interest
00749     @param  ac      The count of arguments in <tt>av</tt>
00750     @param  av      Array of t_atoms; the new desired data for the object
00751 
00752     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
00753                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
00754 
00755     @remark         Developers wishing to design objects which will support this function being called on them must define and implement a special method, <tt>setvalueof</tt>, like so:
00756     @code
00757     class_addmethod(c, (method)myobject_setvalueof, "setvalueof", A_CANT, 0);
00758     @endcode
00759 
00760     @remark         The <tt>setvalueof</tt> method should be prototyped as:
00761     @code
00762     t_max_err myobject_setvalueof(t_myobject *x, long *ac, t_atom **av);
00763     @endcode
00764 
00765     @remark         And implemented, generally, as:
00766     @code
00767     t_max_err myobject_setvalueof(t_myobject *x, long ac, t_atom *av)
00768     {
00769         if (ac && av) {
00770             // simulate receipt of a float value
00771             myobject_float(x, atom_getfloat(av));
00772         }
00773         return MAX_ERR_NONE;
00774     }
00775     @endcode
00776 */
00777 t_max_err object_setvalueof(void *x, long ac, t_atom *av);
00778

00799

00802     @param  x           Pointer to the object whose attribute is of interest
00803     @param  methodname  The Max message used to call the attribute's <tt>get</tt> or <tt>set</tt> function. For example, <tt>gensym("mode")</tt> or <tt>gensym("getthresh")</tt>.
00804     @param  attr        A pointer to a void *, which will be set to the attribute pointer upon successful completion of the function
00805     @param  get         A pointer to a long variable, which will be set to 1 upon successful completion of the function, 
00806                         if the queried method corresponds to the <tt>get</tt> function of the attribute.

00920 /**
00921     Registers the byte-offset of the obex member of the class's data structure with the previously defined object class. 
00922     Use of this function is required for obex-class objects. It must be called from <tt>main()</tt>.
00923 
00924     @ingroup class
00925 
00926     @param  c           The class pointer
00927     @param  offset      The byte-offset to the obex member of the object's data structure. 
00928                         Conventionally, the macro #calcoffset is used to calculate the offset.
00929 */
00930 void class_obexoffset_set(t_class *c, long offset);
00931 
00932 
00933 /**
00934     Retrieves the byte-offset of the obex member of the class's data structure.
00935 
00936     @ingroup    class
00937     @param  c   The class pointer
00938     @return     This function returns the byte-offset of the obex member of the class's data structure.
00939 */
00940 long class_obexoffset_get(t_class *c);
00941 
00942 
00943 /**
00944     Retrieves the value of a data stored in the obex. 
00945 
00946     @ingroup obj
00947 
00948     @param  x       The object pointer. This function should only be called on instantiated objects (i.e. in the <tt>new</tt> method or later), not directly on classes (i.e. in <tt>main()</tt>).
00949     @param  key     The symbolic name for the data to be retrieved
00950     @param  val     A pointer to a #t_object *, to be filled with the data retrieved from the obex.
00951 
00952     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
00953                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
00954 
00955     @remark         By default, pointers to the object's containing patcher and box objects are stored in the obex, under the keys '#P' and '#B', respectively. 
00956                     To retrieve them, the developer could do something like the following:
00957     @code
00958     void post_containers(t_obexobj *x)
00959     {
00960         t_patcher *p;
00961         t_box *b;
00962 
00963         p = object_obex_lookup(x, gensym("#P"), (t_object **)&p);
00964         b = object_obex_lookup(x, gensym("#B"), (t_object **)&b);
00965 
00966         post("my patcher is located at 0x%X", p);
00967         post("my box is located at 0x%X", b);
00968     }
00969     @endcode
00970 */
00971 t_max_err object_obex_lookup(void *x, t_symbol *key, t_object **val);
00972 
00973 
00974 /**
00975     Stores data in the object's obex. 
00976 
00977     @ingroup obj
00978 
00979     @param  x       The object pointer. This function should only be called on instantiated objects (i.e. in the <tt>new</tt> method or later), not directly on classes (i.e. in <tt>main()</tt>).
00980     @param  key     A symbolic name for the data to be stored
00981     @param  val     A #t_object *, to be stored in the obex, referenced under the <tt>key</tt>.
00982 
00983     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
00984                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
00985 
00986     @remark         Most developers will need to use this function for the specific purpose of storing the dumpout outlet in the obex 
00987                     (the dumpout outlet is used by attributes to report data in response to 'get' queries). 
00988                     For this, the developer should use something like the following in the object's <tt>new</tt> method:
00989     @code
00990     object_obex_store(x, _sym_dumpout, outlet_new(x, NULL));
00991     @endcode
00992 */
00993 t_max_err object_obex_store(void *x,t_symbol *key, t_object *val);
00994 t_max_err object_obex_storeflags(void *x,t_symbol *key, t_object *val, long flags);
00995

01002 t_hashtab *object_obex_get(void *x);
01003

01009 /**
01010     Sends data from the object's dumpout outlet. 
01011     The dumpout outlet is stored in the obex using the object_obex_store() function (see above).
01012     It is used approximately like outlet_anything().
01013 
01014     @ingroup obj
01015 
01016     @param  x       The object pointer. 
01017                     This function should only be called on instantiated objects (i.e. in the <tt>new</tt> method or later), not directly on classes (i.e. in <tt>main()</tt>).
01018     @param  s       The message selector #t_symbol *
01019     @param  argc    Number of elements in the argument list in argv
01020     @param  argv    t_atoms constituting the message arguments
01021 
01022     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
01023                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
01024 */
01025 void object_obex_dumpout(void *x, t_symbol *s, long argc, t_atom *argv);

01033 /**
01034     Inserts an integer into a #t_atom and change the t_atom's type to #A_LONG. 
01035

01037 
01038     @param  a       Pointer to a #t_atom whose value and type will be modified
01039     @param  b       Integer value to copy into the #t_atom
01040 
01041     @return     This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
01042                 or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
01043 */
01044 t_max_err atom_setlong(t_atom *a, long b);
01045 
01046 
01047 /**
01048     Inserts a floating point number into a #t_atom and change the t_atom's type to #A_FLOAT. 
01049 
01050     @ingroup atom
01051 
01052     @param  a       Pointer to a #t_atom whose value and type will be modified
01053     @param  b       Floating point value to copy into the #t_atom
01054 
01055     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
01056                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
01057 */
01058 t_max_err atom_setfloat(t_atom *a, double b);
01059

01061 /**
01062     Inserts a #t_symbol * into a #t_atom and change the t_atom's type to #A_SYM. 
01063 
01064     @ingroup atom

01067     @param  b       Pointer to a #t_symbol to copy into the #t_atom
01068

01070                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
01071 */
01072 t_max_err atom_setsym(t_atom *a, t_symbol *b);              
01073 
01074 
01075 /**
01076     Inserts a generic pointer value into a #t_atom and change the t_atom's type to #A_OBJ. 
01077 
01078     @ingroup atom
01079 
01080     @param  a       Pointer to a #t_atom whose value and type will be modified
01081     @param  b       Pointer value to copy into the #t_atom
01082     
01083     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
01084                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
01085 */
01086 t_max_err atom_setobj(t_atom *a, void *b);
01087 
01088 
01089 /**
01090     Retrieves a long integer value from a #t_atom. 
01091 
01092     @ingroup atom
01093 
01094     @param  a       Pointer to a #t_atom whose value is of interest
01095     @return         This function returns the value of the specified #t_atom as an integer, if possible. Otherwise, it returns 0. 
01096     @remark         If the #t_atom is not of the type specified by the function, the function will attempt to coerce a valid value from the t_atom. 
01097                     For instance, if the t_atom <tt>at</tt> is set to type #A_FLOAT with a value of <tt>3.7</tt>, 
01098                     the atom_getlong() function will return the truncated integer value of <tt>at</tt>, or <tt>3</tt>. 
01099                     An attempt is also made to coerce #t_symbol data.
01100 */
01101 long atom_getlong(t_atom *a);
01102 
01103 
01104 /**
01105     Retrieves a floating point value from a #t_atom. 
01106 
01107     @ingroup atom
01108     @param  a       Pointer to a #t_atom whose value is of interest
01109     @return         This function returns the value of the specified #t_atom as a floating point number, if possible. Otherwise, it returns 0. 
01110 
01111     @remark         If the #t_atom is not of the type specified by the function, the function will attempt to coerce a valid value from the t_atom. 
01112                     For instance, if the t_atom <tt>at</tt> is set to type #A_LONG with a value of <tt>5</tt>, 
01113                     the atom_getfloat() function will return the value of <tt>at</tt> as a float, or <tt>5.0</tt>. 
01114                     An attempt is also made to coerce #t_symbol data.
01115 */
01116 float atom_getfloat(t_atom *a);
01117 
01118 
01119 /**
01120     Retrieves a t_symbol * value from a t_atom. 
01121 
01122     @ingroup atom
01123     @param  a       Pointer to a t_atom whose value is of interest
01124     @return         This function returns the value of the specified #A_SYM-typed #t_atom, if possible. 
01125                     Otherwise, it returns an empty, but valid, #t_symbol *, equivalent to <tt>gensym("")</tt>, or <tt>_sym_nothing</tt>. 
01126 
01127     @remark         No attempt is made to coerce non-matching data types. 
01128 */
01129 t_symbol *atom_getsym(t_atom *a);
01130 
01131 
01132 /**
01133     Retrieves a generic pointer value from a #t_atom. 
01134 
01135     @ingroup atom
01136     @param  a       Pointer to a #t_atom whose value is of interest
01137     @return         This function returns the value of the specified #A_OBJ-typed t_atom, if possible. Otherwise, it returns NULL. 
01138 */
01139 void *atom_getobj(t_atom *a);
01140 
01141 
01142 /**
01143     Retrieves an unsigned integer value between 0 and 255 from a t_atom. 
01144 
01145     @ingroup atom
01146     @param  a       Pointer to a #t_atom whose value is of interest
01147     @return         This function returns the value of the specified #t_atom as an integer between 0 and 255, if possible. Otherwise, it returns 0. 
01148 
01149     @remark         If the #t_atom is typed #A_LONG, but the data falls outside of the range 0-255, the data is truncated to that range before output.
01150 
01151     @remark         If the t_atom is typed #A_FLOAT, the floating point value is multiplied by 255. and truncated to the range 0-255 before output. 
01152                     For example, the floating point value <tt>0.5</tt> would be output from atom_getcharfix as <tt>127</tt> (0.5 * 255. = 127.5). 
01153 
01154     @remark         No attempt is also made to coerce #t_symbol data. 
01155 */
01156 long atom_getcharfix(t_atom *a);
01157 
01158 
01159 /**
01160     Retrieves type from a #t_atom. 
01161 
01162     @ingroup atom
01163     @param  a       Pointer to a #t_atom whose type is of interest
01164     @return         This function returns the type of the specified t_atom as defined in #e_max_atomtypes
01165 */
01166 long atom_gettype(t_atom *a);
01167 
01168 
01169 //the following are useful for setting the values _only_ if there is an arg
01170 //rather than setting it to 0 or _sym_nothing
01171 
01172 /**
01173     Retrieves the integer value of a particular t_atom from an atom list, if the atom exists.
01174 
01175     @ingroup atom
01176 
01177     @param  c       Pointer to a long variable to receive the atom's data if the function is successful.
01178     @param  idx     Offset into the atom list of the atom of interest, starting from 0. 
01179                     For instance, if you want data from the 3rd atom in the atom list, <tt>idx</tt> should be set to 2.
01180     @param  ac      Count of av.
01181     @param  av      Pointer to the first t_atom of an atom list.
01182 
01183     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
01184                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
01185 
01186     @remark         The atom_arg_getlong() function only changes the value of <tt>c</tt> if the function is successful. 
01187                     For instance, the following code snippet illustrates a simple, but typical use:
01188     @code
01189     void myobject_mymessage(t_myobject *x, t_symbol *s, long ac, t_atom *av)
01190     {
01191         long var = -1;
01192 
01193         // here, we are expecting a value of 0 or greater
01194         atom_arg_getlong(&var, 0, ac, av);
01195         if (val == -1) // i.e. unchanged
01196             post("it is likely that the user did not provide a valid argument");
01197         else {
01198             ...
01199         }
01200     }
01201     @endcode
01202 */
01203 long atom_arg_getlong(long *c, long idx, long ac, t_atom *av);
01204 
01205 
01206 /**
01207     Retrieves the floating point value of a particular t_atom from an atom list, if the atom exists.
01208 
01209     @ingroup atom
01210 
01211     @param  c       Pointer to a float variable to receive the atom's data if the function is successful. Otherwise, the value is left unchanged.
01212     @param  idx     Offset into the atom list of the atom of interest, starting from 0. 
01213                     For instance, if you want data from the 3rd atom in the atom list, <tt>idx</tt> should be set to 2.
01214     @param  ac      Count of av.
01215     @param  av      Pointer to the first t_atom of an atom list.
01216 
01217     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
01218                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
01219 */
01220 long atom_arg_getfloat(float *c, long idx, long ac, t_atom *av);
01221 
01222 
01223 /**
01224     Retrieves the floating point value, as a double, of a particular t_atom from an atom list, if the atom exists.
01225 
01226     @ingroup atom
01227 
01228     @param  c       Pointer to a double variable to receive the atom's data if the function is successful. Otherwise the value is left unchanged.
01229     @param  idx     Offset into the atom list of the atom of interest, starting from 0. 
01230                     For instance, if you want data from the 3rd atom in the atom list, <tt>idx</tt> should be set to 2.
01231     @param  ac      Count of av.
01232     @param  av      Pointer to the first t_atom of an atom list.
01233 
01234     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
01235                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
01236 */
01237 long atom_arg_getdouble(double *c, long idx, long ac, t_atom *av);
01238 
01239 
01240 /**
01241     Retrieves the t_symbol * value of a particular t_atom from an atom list, if the atom exists.
01242 
01243     @ingroup atom
01244 
01245     @param  c       Pointer to a t_symbol * variable to receive the atom's data if the function is successful. Otherwise, the value is left unchanged.
01246     @param  idx     Offset into the atom list of the atom of interest, starting from 0. 
01247                     For instance, if you want data from the 3rd atom in the atom list, <tt>idx</tt> should be set to 2.
01248     @param  ac      Count of av.
01249     @param  av      Pointer to the first t_atom of an atom list.
01250 
01251     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
01252                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
01253 
01254     @remark         The atom_arg_getsym() function only changes the value of <tt>c</tt> if the function is successful. 
01255                     For instance, the following code snippet illustrates a simple, but typical use:
01256     @code
01257     void myobject_open(t_myobject *x, t_symbol *s, long ac, t_atom *av)
01258     {
01259         t_symbol *filename = _sym_nothing;
01260 
01261         // here, we are expecting a file name.
01262         // if we don't get it, open a dialog box 
01263         atom_arg_getsym(&filename, 0, ac, av);
01264         if (filename == _sym_nothing) { // i.e. unchanged
01265             // open the file dialog box,
01266             // get a value for filename
01267         }
01268         // do something with the filename
01269     }
01270     @endcode
01271 */
01272 long atom_arg_getsym(t_symbol **c, long idx, long ac, t_atom *av);
01273 
01274 
01275 //attr functions
01276 
01277 /**
01278     Determines the point in an atom list where attribute arguments begin. 
01279     Developers can use this function to assist in the manual processing of attribute arguments, when attr_args_process() 
01280     doesn't provide the correct functionality for a particular purpose.
01281 
01282     @ingroup attr
01283 
01284     @param  ac      The count of t_atoms in <tt>av</tt>
01285     @param  av      An atom list
01286 
01287     @return         This function returns an offset into the atom list, where the first attribute argument occurs. 
01288                     For instance, the atom list <tt>foo bar 3.0 \@mode 6</tt> would cause <tt>attr_args_offset</tt> to return 3 
01289                     (the attribute <tt>mode</tt> appears at position 3 in the atom list).
01290 */
01291 long attr_args_offset(short ac, t_atom *av);
01292 
01293 
01294 /**
01295     Takes an atom list and properly set any attributes described within. This function is typically used in an object's <tt>new</tt> method to conveniently process attribute arguments.
01296 
01297     @ingroup attr
01298 
01299     @param  x       The object whose attributes will be processed
01300     @param  ac      The count of t_atoms in <tt>av</tt>
01301     @param  av      An atom list
01302 
01303     @remark         Here is a typical example of usage:
01304     @code
01305     void *myobject_new(t_symbol *s, long ac, t_atom *av)
01306     {
01307         t_myobject *x = NULL;
01308 
01309         if (x=(t_myobject *)object_alloc(myobject_class))
01310         {
01311             // initialize any data before processing
01312             // attributes to avoid overwriting 
01313             // attribute argument-set values
01314             x->data = 0; 
01315 
01316             // process attr args, if any
01317             attr_args_process(x, ac, av);
01318         }
01319         return x;
01320     }
01321     @endcode
01322 */
01323 void attr_args_process(void *x, short ac, t_atom *av);
01324 
01325 
01326 //constructors
01327 
01328 
01329 /**
01330     Create a new attribute. The attribute will allocate memory and store its own data. Attributes created using attribute_new() can be assigned either to classes (using the class_addattr() function) or to objects (using the object_addattr() function).
01331 
01332     @ingroup attr
01333 
01334     @param  name    A name for the attribute, as a C-string
01335     @param  type    A t_symbol * representing a valid attribute type. 
01336                     At the time of this writing, the valid type-symbols are: 
01337                     <tt>_sym_char</tt> (char), 
01338                     <tt>_sym_long</tt> (long), 
01339                     <tt>_sym_float32</tt> (32-bit float), 
01340                     <tt>_sym_float64</tt> (64-bit float), 
01341                     <tt>_sym_atom</tt> (Max #t_atom pointer), 
01342                     <tt>_sym_symbol</tt> (Max #t_symbol pointer), 
01343                     <tt>_sym_pointer</tt> (generic pointer) and 
01344                     <tt>_sym_object</tt> (Max #t_object pointer).
01345     @param  flags   Any attribute flags, expressed as a bitfield. 
01346                     Attribute flags are used to determine if an attribute is accessible for setting or querying. 
01347                     The available accessor flags are defined in #e_max_attrflags.                   
01348     @param  mget    The method to use for the attribute's <tt>get</tt> functionality. If <tt>mget</tt> is NULL, the default method is used. 
01349     @param  mset    The method to use for the attribute's <tt>set</tt> functionality. If <tt>mset</tt> is NULL, the default method is used.
01350 
01351     @return         This function returns the new attribute's object pointer if successful, or NULL if unsuccessful.
01352 
01353     @remark         Developers wishing to define custom methods for <tt>get</tt> or <tt>set</tt> functionality need to prototype them as:
01354     @code
01355     t_max_err myobject_myattr_get(t_myobject *x, void *attr, long *ac, t_atom **av);
01356     @endcode
01357     @code
01358     t_max_err myobject_myattr_set(t_myobject *x, void *attr, long ac, t_atom *av);
01359     @endcode
01360 
01361     @remark         Implementation will vary, of course, but need to follow the following basic models. 
01362                     Note that, as with custom <tt>getvalueof</tt> and <tt>setvalueof</tt> methods for the object, 
01363                     assumptions are made throughout Max that getbytes() has been used for memory allocation. 
01364                     Developers are strongly urged to do the same:
01365     @code
01366     t_max_err myobject_myattr_get(t_myobject *x, void *attr, long *ac, t_atom **av)
01367     {
01368         if (*ac && *av)
01369             // memory passed in; use it
01370         else {
01371             *ac = 1; // size of attr data
01372             *av = (t_atom *)getbytes(sizeof(t_atom) * (*ac));
01373             if (!(*av)) {
01374                 *ac = 0;
01375                 return MAX_ERR_OUT_OF_MEM;
01376             }
01377         }
01378         atom_setlong(*av, x->some_value);
01379         return MAX_ERR_NONE;
01380     }
01381 
01382     t_max_err myobject_myattr_set(t_myobject *x, void *attr, long ac, t_atom *av)
01383     {
01384         if (ac && av) {
01385             x->some_value = atom_getlong(av);
01386         }
01387         return MAX_ERR_NONE;
01388     }
01389     @endcode
01390 */
01391 t_object *attribute_new(char *name, t_symbol *type, long flags, method mget, method mset);
01392 
01393 
01394 /**
01395     Create a new attribute. The attribute references memory stored outside of itself, in the object's data structure. Attributes created using attr_offset_new() can be assigned either to classes (using the class_addattr() function) or to objects (using the object_addattr() function).
01396 
01397     @ingroup attr
01398 
01399     @param  name    A name for the attribute, as a C-string
01400     @param  type    A t_symbol * representing a valid attribute type. 
01401                     At the time of this writing, the valid type-symbols are: 
01402                     <tt>_sym_char</tt> (char), 
01403                     <tt>_sym_long</tt> (long), 
01404                     <tt>_sym_float32</tt> (32-bit float), 
01405                     <tt>_sym_float64</tt> (64-bit float), 
01406                     <tt>_sym_atom</tt> (Max #t_atom pointer), 
01407                     <tt>_sym_symbol</tt> (Max #t_symbol pointer), 
01408                     <tt>_sym_pointer</tt> (generic pointer) and 
01409                     <tt>_sym_object</tt> (Max #t_object pointer).
01410     @param  flags   Any attribute flags, expressed as a bitfield. 
01411                     Attribute flags are used to determine if an attribute is accessible for setting or querying. 
01412                     The available accessor flags are defined in #e_max_attrflags.                   
01413     @param  mget    The method to use for the attribute's <tt>get</tt> functionality. 
01414                     If <tt>mget</tt> is NULL, the default method is used. See the discussion under attribute_new(), for more information.
01415     @param  mset    The method to use for the attribute's <tt>set</tt> functionality. 
01416                     If <tt>mset</tt> is NULL, the default method is used. See the discussion under attribute_new(), for more information.
01417     @param  offset  Byte offset into the class data structure of the object which will "own" the attribute. 
01418                     The offset should point to the data to be referenced by the attribute. 
01419                     Typically, the #calcoffset macro (described above) is used to calculate this offset.
01420 
01421     @return         This function returns the new attribute's object pointer if successful, or NULL if unsuccessful.
01422 
01423     @remark         For instance, to create a new attribute which references the value of a double variable (<tt>val</tt>) in an object class's data structure:
01424     @code
01425     t_object *attr = attr_offset_new("myattr", _sym_float64 / * matches data size * /, 0 / * no flags * /, (method)0L, (method)0L, calcoffset(t_myobject, val));
01426     @endcode
01427 */
01428 t_object *attr_offset_new(char *name, t_symbol *type, long flags, method mget, method mset, long offset);
01429 
01430 
01431 /**
01432     Create a new attribute. The attribute references an array of memory stored outside of itself, in the object's data structure. Attributes created using attr_offset_array_new() can be assigned either to classes (using the class_addattr() function) or to objects (using the object_addattr() function).
01433 
01434     @ingroup attr
01435 
01436     @param  name        A name for the attribute, as a C-string
01437     @param  type        A t_symbol * representing a valid attribute type. 
01438                         At the time of this writing, the valid type-symbols are: 
01439                         <tt>_sym_char</tt> (char), 
01440                         <tt>_sym_long</tt> (long), 
01441                         <tt>_sym_float32</tt> (32-bit float), 
01442                         <tt>_sym_float64</tt> (64-bit float), 
01443                         <tt>_sym_atom</tt> (Max #t_atom pointer), 
01444                         <tt>_sym_symbol</tt> (Max #t_symbol pointer), 
01445                         <tt>_sym_pointer</tt> (generic pointer) and 
01446                         <tt>_sym_object</tt> (Max #t_object pointer).
01447     @param  size        Maximum number of items that may be in the array.
01448     @param  flags       Any attribute flags, expressed as a bitfield. 
01449                         Attribute flags are used to determine if an attribute is accessible for setting or querying. 
01450                         The available accessor flags are defined in #e_max_attrflags.                   
01451     @param  mget        The method to use for the attribute's <tt>get</tt> functionality. 
01452                         If <tt>mget</tt> is NULL, the default method is used. See the discussion under attribute_new(), for more information.
01453     @param  mset        The method to use for the attribute's <tt>set</tt> functionality. 
01454                         If <tt>mset</tt> is NULL, the default method is used. See the discussion under attribute_new(), for more information.
01455     @param  offsetcount Byte offset into the object class's data structure of a long variable describing how many array elements 
01456                         (up to <tt>size</tt>) comprise the data to be referenced by the attribute. 
01457                         Typically, the #calcoffset macro is used to calculate this offset.
01458     @param  offset      Byte offset into the class data structure of the object which will "own" the attribute. 
01459                         The offset should point to the data to be referenced by the attribute. 
01460                         Typically, the #calcoffset macro is used to calculate this offset.
01461 
01462     @return             This function returns the new attribute's object pointer if successful, or NULL if unsuccessful.
01463 
01464     @remark             For instance, to create a new attribute which references an array of 10 t_atoms (<tt>atm</tt>; 
01465                         the current number of "active" elements in the array is held in the variable <tt>atmcount</tt>) in an object class's data structure:
01466     @code
01467     t_object *attr = attr_offset_array_new("myattrarray", _sym_atom / * matches data size * /, 10 / * max * /, 0 / * no flags * /, (method)0L, (method)0L, calcoffset(t_myobject, atmcount) / * count * /, calcoffset(t_myobject, atm) / * data * /);
01468     @endcode
01469 */
01470 t_object *attr_offset_array_new(char *name, t_symbol *type, long size, long flags, method mget, method mset, long offsetcount, long offset);

01473 t_object *attr_filter_clip_new(void);

01476 t_object *attr_filter_proc_new(method proc);

01666 long object_attr_getfloat_array(void *x, t_symbol *s, long max, float *vals);
01667 
01668 
01669 /**
01670     Sets the value of an attribute, given its parent object and name. The function will call the attribute's <tt>set</tt> method, using the data provided.
01671 
01672     @ingroup attr
01673 
01674     @param  x       The attribute's parent object
01675     @param  s       The attribute's name
01676     @param  count   The number of array elements in vals
01677     @param  vals    Pointer to the first element of an array of float data
01678 
01679     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
01680                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
01681 */
01682 t_max_err object_attr_setfloat_array(void *x, t_symbol *s, long count, float *vals);
01683 
01684 
01685 /**
01686     Retrieves the value of an attribute, given its parent object and name. 
01687     This function uses a developer-allocated array to copy data to. 
01688     Developers wishing to retrieve the value of an attribute without pre-allocating memory should refer to the object_attr_getvalueof() function.
01689 
01690     @ingroup attr
01691 
01692     @param  x       The attribute's parent object
01693     @param  s       The attribute's name
01694     @param  max     The number of array elements in <tt>vals</tt>. The function will take care not to overwrite the bounds of the array.
01695     @param  vals    Pointer to the first element of a pre-allocated array of double data.
01696 
01697     @return         This function returns the number of elements copied into <tt>vals</tt>.
01698 
01699     @remark         If the attribute is not of the type specified by the function, the 
01700                     function will attempt to coerce a valid value from the attribute.
01701 */
01702 long object_attr_getdouble_array(void *x, t_symbol *s, long max, double *vals);
01703 
01704 
01705 /**
01706     Sets the value of an attribute, given its parent object and name. The function will call the attribute's <tt>set</tt> method, using the data provided.
01707 
01708     @ingroup attr

01710     @param  x       The attribute's parent object
01711     @param  s       The attribute's name
01712     @param  count   The number of array elements in vals
01713     @param  vals    Pointer to the first element of an array of double data
01714 
01715     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
01716                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
01717 */
01718 t_max_err object_attr_setdouble_array(void *x, t_symbol *s, long count, double *vals);

01725

01727

01757 /**
01758     Attaches a clip filter to an attribute. 
01759     The filter will <em>only</em> clip values sent to the attribute using the attribute's <tt>set</tt> function.
01760 
01761     @ingroup attr
01762 
01763     @param  x       Pointer to the attribute to receive the filter
01764     @param  min     Minimum value for the clip filter
01765     @param  max     Maximum value for the clip filter 
01766     @param  usemin  Sets this value to 0 if the minimum clip value should <em>not</em> be used. Otherwise, set the value to non-zero.
01767     @param  usemax  Sets this value to 0 if the minimum clip value should <em>not</em> be used. Otherwise, set the value to non-zero.
01768 
01769     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
01770                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
01771 */
01772 t_max_err attr_addfilterset_clip(void *x, double min, double max, long usemin, long usemax);
01773 
01774 
01775 /**
01776     Attaches a clip/scale filter to an attribute. 
01777     The filter will <em>only</em> clip and scale values sent to the attribute using the attribute's <tt>set</tt> function.
01778 
01779     @ingroup attr
01780 
01781     @param  x       Pointer to the attribute to receive the filter
01782     @param  scale   Scale value. Data sent to the attribute will be scaled by this amount. <em>Scaling occurs previous to clipping</em>.
01783     @param  min     Minimum value for the clip filter
01784     @param  max     Maximum value for the clip filter 
01785     @param  usemin  Sets this value to 0 if the minimum clip value should <em>not</em> be used. Otherwise, set the value to non-zero.
01786     @param  usemax  Sets this value to 0 if the minimum clip value should <em>not</em> be used. Otherwise, set the value to non-zero.
01787 
01788     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
01789                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
01790 */
01791 t_max_err attr_addfilterset_clip_scale(void *x, double scale, double min, double max, long usemin, long usemax);
01792 
01793 
01794 /**
01795     Attaches a clip filter to an attribute. 
01796     The filter will <em>only</em> clip values retrieved from the attribute using the attribute's <tt>get</tt> function.
01797 
01798     @ingroup attr
01799 
01800     @param  x       Pointer to the attribute to receive the filter
01801     @param  min     Minimum value for the clip filter
01802     @param  max     Maximum value for the clip filter 
01803     @param  usemin  Sets this value to 0 if the minimum clip value should <em>not</em> be used. Otherwise, set the value to non-zero.
01804     @param  usemax  Sets this value to 0 if the minimum clip value should <em>not</em> be used. Otherwise, set the value to non-zero.
01805 
01806     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
01807                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
01808 */
01809 t_max_err attr_addfilterget_clip(void *x, double min, double max, long usemin, long usemax);

01832     Attaches a clip filter to an attribute. 
01833     The filter will clip any values sent to or retrieved from the attribute using the attribute's <tt>get</tt> and <tt>set</tt> functions.
01834 
01835     @ingroup attr
01836 
01837     @param  x       Pointer to the attribute to receive the filter
01838     @param  min     Minimum value for the clip filter
01839     @param  max     Maximum value for the clip filter 
01840     @param  usemin  Sets this value to 0 if the minimum clip value should <em>not</em> be used. Otherwise, set the value to non-zero.
01841     @param  usemax  Sets this value to 0 if the minimum clip value should <em>not</em> be used. Otherwise, set the value to non-zero.
01842

01844                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.

01849 /**
01850     Attaches a clip/scale filter to an attribute. 
01851     The filter will clip and scale any values sent to or retrieved from the attribute using the attribute's <tt>get</tt> and <tt>set</tt> functions.
01852 
01853     @ingroup attr
01854 
01855     @param  x       Pointer to the attribute to receive the filter
01856     @param  scale   Scale value. Data sent to the attribute will be scaled by this amount. Data retrieved from the attribute will be scaled by its reciprocal. 
01857                     <em>Scaling occurs previous to clipping</em>.
01858     @param  min     Minimum value for the clip filter
01859     @param  max     Maximum value for the clip filter 
01860     @param  usemin  Sets this value to 0 if the minimum clip value should <em>not</em> be used. Otherwise, set the value to non-zero.
01861     @param  usemax  Sets this value to 0 if the minimum clip value should <em>not</em> be used. Otherwise, set the value to non-zero.
01862 
01863     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
01864                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
01865 */
01866 t_max_err attr_addfilter_clip_scale(void *x, double scale, double min, double max, long usemin, long usemax);
01867 
01868 
01869 /**
01870     Attaches a custom filter method to an attribute. 
01871     The filter will <em>only</em> be called for values retrieved from the attribute using the attribute's <tt>set</tt> function.
01872 
01873     @ingroup attr
01874 
01875     @param  x       Pointer to the attribute to receive the filter
01876     @param  proc    A filter method
01877 
01878     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
01879                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
01880 
01881     @remark         The filter method should be prototyped and implemented as follows:
01882     @code
01883     t_max_err myfiltermethod(void *parent, void *attr, long ac, t_atom *av);
01884 
01885     t_max_err myfiltermethod(void *parent, void *attr, long ac, t_atom *av)
01886     {
01887         long i;
01888         float temp,
01889 
01890         // this filter rounds off all values
01891         // assumes that the data is float 
01892         for (i = 0; i < ac; i++) {
01893             temp = atom_getfloat(av + i);
01894             temp = (float)((long)(temp + 0.5));
01895             atom_setfloat(av + i, temp);
01896         }
01897         return MAX_ERR_NONE;
01898     }
01899     @endcode
01900 */
01901 t_max_err attr_addfilterset_proc(void *x, method proc);
01902 
01903 
01904 /**
01905     Attaches a custom filter method to an attribute. The filter will <em>only</em> be called for values retrieved from the attribute using the attribute's <tt>get</tt> function.
01906 
01907     @ingroup attr
01908 
01909     @param  x       Pointer to the attribute to receive the filter
01910     @param  proc    A filter method
01911 
01912     @return         This function returns the error code #MAX_ERR_NONE if successful, 
01913                     or one of the other error codes defined in #e_max_errorcodes if unsuccessful.
01914 
01915     @remark         The filter method should be prototyped and implemented as described above for the attr_addfilterset_proc() function.
01916 */
01917 t_max_err attr_addfilterget_proc(void *x, method proc);

01992 /**
01993     Create a dictionary of attribute-name, attribute-value pairs 
01994     from an array of atoms containing an attribute definition list.
01995     
01996     @ingroup attr
01997     @param  x   A dictionary instance pointer.
01998     @param  ac  The number of atoms to parse in av.
01999     @param  av  A pointer to the first of the array of atoms containing the attribute values.
02000 
02001     @remark     The code example below shows the creation of a list of atoms using atom_setparse(),
02002                 and then uses that list of atoms to fill the dictionary with attr_args_dictionary().
02003     @code
02004     long ac = 0;
02005     t_atom *av = NULL;
02006     char parsebuf[4096];
02007     t_dictionary *d = dictionary_new();
02008     t_atom a;
02009     
02010     sprintf(parsebuf,"@defrect %.6f %.6f %.6f %.6f @title Untitled @presentation 0 ", r->x, r->y, r->width, r->height);
02011     atom_setparse(&ac, &av, parsebuf);
02012     attr_args_dictionary(d, ac, av);
02013     atom_setobj(&a, d);
02014     @endcode
02015 */
02016 void attr_args_dictionary(t_dictionary *x, short ac, t_atom *av);
02017

02020     Set attributes for an object that are defined in a dictionary.
02021     Objects with dictionary constructors, such as UI objects,

02025     @param  x   The object instance pointer.

02083 
02084 /**
02085     Allocate a single atom.
02086     If ac and av are both zero then memory is allocated.
02087     Otherwise it is presumed that memory is already allocated and nothing will happen.
02088 
02089     @ingroup        atom
02090     @param  ac      The address of a variable that will contain the number of atoms allocated (1).
02091     @param  av      The address of a pointer that will be set with the new allocated memory for the atom.
02092     @param  alloc   Address of a variable that will be set true is memory is allocated, otherwise false.
02093     @return         A Max error code.
02094 */
02095 t_max_err atom_alloc(long *ac, t_atom **av, char *alloc);
02096 
02097 
02098 /**
02099     Allocate an array of atoms.
02100     If ac and av are both zero then memory is allocated.
02101     Otherwise it is presumed that memory is already allocated and nothing will happen.
02102 
02103     @ingroup        atom
02104     @param  minsize The minimum number of atoms that this array will need to contain.
02105                     This determines the amount of memory allocated.
02106     @param  ac      The address of a variable that will contain the number of atoms allocated.
02107     @param  av      The address of a pointer that will be set with the new allocated memory for the atoms.
02108     @param  alloc   Address of a variable that will be set true is memory is allocated, otherwise false.
02109     @return         A Max error code.
02110 */
02111 t_max_err atom_alloc_array(long minsize, long *ac, t_atom **av, char *alloc);
